info.title: Maintaining data integrity of AI applications

abstract.para: This topic describes how to avoid compromising AI applications and keep sensitive data secure.

section.title: Why care about the security of AI applications?
section.para: AI applications use AI-driven chatbots to interact with users. These chatbots are powered by large language models (LLMs) and can process external data sources (RAGs). Such applications are prone to cyber attacks as any other software solutions. Attackers may impersonate users and apply a series of techniques to steal data and to corrupt the responses provided by AI models.

section.title: Which &productname; components are prone to attacks
section.para: Users interact with &productname; via the &owui; user interface. With &owui;, you can manage users, permissions, AI models, knowledge bases, and chat interactions. The following &productname; components are the most susceptible to security attacks:

listitem.para: &owui; enables you to specify external data sources to improve responses. On a user level, you can append documents directly to the chat input field. With administrator privileges, you can upload documents to create a knowledge base that enhances the AI model. The knowledge base acts as a domain specific augmentation tool for the LLM. It prevents chatbot hallucination and improves the model's responses with accurate and up-to-date information.

tip.para: Actions performed by users—both the administrators and guests—are logged into an audit log. With the audit log, it is possible to map all actions that took the system to its current state.

listitem.para: It is possible to input documents directly into &milvus;—the vector database responsible for the low level implementation of the knowledge base concept. Although the user interaction normally takes place via &owui;, attackers may bypass &owui; to interact with &milvus;. This can happen if no identity access management (IAM) policy is controlling database access.

&ollama; manages the interactions with several LLMs. It can search, download, start and manage models within a unified interface. &ollama; does not offer authentication and authorization by default. Therefore, &ollama;'s API should not be exposed without a an element providing IAM capabilities. In &productname;, user interacts with &ollama; via &owui;, which is able to configure and secure &ollama;.

section.title: What are common attacks and security risks?
section.para: This section lists several attacks and security risks related to AI applications.

listitem.para: A common exploit when a knowledge base—often a vector database—that provides context for the AI model responses, is corrupted by the addition of documents with misleading, false or even harmful content. The malicious documents tend to be crafted specifically to provide wrong answers for a set of user prompts. This kind of attack usually requires access to a user with privileges to configure the whole platform or the vector databases that support the platform.

RAG-powered models can search knowledge bases, summarize content and provide references. Attackers may use these characteristics to discover and retrieve organizational data with simple prompts instead of relying on more refined data-exploitation techniques.
User prompts may contain sensitive data, so chat caches and system logs need to be protected against attackers.

section.title: What safety measures should my organization follow?
section.para: To avoid having your system corrupted, there are a few security measures that need to be properly implemented. &owui; and &milvus; allow high level user access configurations. Besides these high level configurations, provide access management with low level network configurations. To verify that your whole AI stack is secure, consider the following points:

listitem.para: At the authentication level, limit the creation of guest users.
At the authorization level, never allow new users to be automatically set as system administrators.
Limit the number of users with privileges for adding documents to your knowledge base.
Keep in mind that the same policies set for &owui; need to be propagated in all systems composing the AI stack.
Limit the exposure of internal services (such as &milvus; and &ollama;) to the internet.
Configure authentication and authorization for all components of the AI stack.

varlistentry.term: Adopt an audit log review policy.

listitem.para: Periodically check the audit logs provided in the Web interface, from both the chatbot and the vector databases. Look for abnormal behavior from one or more users.
Avoid saving chat prompts and system logs.

varlistentry.term: Train users to avoid LLM overreliance.

listitem.para: Encourage users to approach the answers from the RAG-based models with a critical mindset. Make sure they are able to verify the references provided by the AI chatbot. Files used in the context of a user prompt are appended to the AI model's answer.
Educate your users about how to report problems with the AI model's answers. Assign responsibilities for the system support.
Remember that when a security breach happens, the sooner the system is restored to a trusted state, the less damage your organization takes.

varlistentry.term: Set up a secure environment for your applications.

listitem.para: Make sure that there are components enforcing authentication and authorization rules over the whole installation of the AI Stack. We recommend to avoid exposing &milvus; and &ollama; without proper network configurations.
